main
Class MonomOnesSubset

java.lang.Object
  main.MonomOnesSubset

public class MonomOnesSubset
extends java.lang.Object

By the implementation of MonomSet we know, that i.e. a list of the following monoms is in the same monomSet, since they have the same signature X-X-XX: 

 0-0-00
 0-1-00
 0-1-10
 1-0-01
 1-1-11
We now want to split this big MonomSet into MonomSubsets which depend on the number of 1s inside the monoms. Algorithmically - due to the QuineMcKlsukey - we devide L_i^M into its subsets which contain a fixed number of ones; i.e. L_i^M(k) would be the subset of L_i^M containing exactly k 1s.
Thus we split the upper example into the subsets: 
 0-0-00 L_i^M(0)
 ******
 0-1-00 L_i^M(1)
 ******
 0-1-10 L_i^M(2)
 1-0-01
 ******
 1-1-11 L_i^M(5)
Note: L_i^M is fixed in the complete somputation of this class, since M represents the signature signature, which is a attribute of the constructor and fixed for the whole class.

Author:
chrissy

Field Detail

signature

protected final java.lang.String signature
The signature of one MonomOne subset is here defined as a constant. We do this because we never want to change the signature.
If we instanciate an Object of this class with the signature "XX-XX-X" the whole Object only works with the given Signature. If we want a new signature we will have to instanciate a new class.

calculatedMaxNumber

protected final int calculatedMaxNumber
We calsulate the maximum number of different sets.
Note: We can use an integer, since the maximum length of a monom is 10. Thus the maximum number of different ones that form the above descripted subsets L_i^M(k); hence the maximum number of k is 2^10 = 1024.
So an int-array is really large enough

lists

java.util.TreeSet[] lists
This is the list array, we will fill in the lists. Each list has a different number of ones and each list represents one L_i^M(k) for each k.

Constructor Detail

MonomOnesSubset

                       java.lang.String signature)
Method Detail

getMaximumNumberOfDifferentSets

protected int getMaximumNumberOfDifferentSets(java.lang.String sig)
We need now many sets - at maximum a complete Powerset.
For example we have the signature 'XX-XX--X'.
Thus we have 5 entries, which is returned by the method getNumberOfEntries. Each of this entry can be 0 or 1. Thus we will have to create 2^5 sets for this signature: 
 0 ones:
 00-00-0
 
 1 one:
 00-00-1
 00-01-0
 00-10-0
 01-00-0
 10-00-0
 
 2 ones:
 00-01-1
 00-10-1
 ...
 and so on
 ...
 ...
 ...
 until
 ...
 
 4 ones:
 01-11-1
 10-11-1
 11-01-1
 11-10-1
 11-11-0
 
 and
 
 5 ones:
 11-11-1
In general we have to create 2^(Number of Xs in the signature) sets. One set for each possible number of ones.
Thus we will return the power of 2 and the possible numer of entries getNumberOfEntries.
Note: Inside the code we add 1 to the exponent to be sure that we have enough sets.

Parameters:
sig - a signature
Returns:
an upper bound to the maximal number of possible different sets

getNumberOfEntries

protected int getNumberOfEntries(java.lang.String sig)
Parameters:
sig - the signature
Returns:
the number of different entries = the number of 'X's in the signature

generateSets

protected void generateSets()
Here comes the big (!) job of creating all sets.
First we initialize the TreeSet-Array lists with the maximum number of possible sets.
Then we fill lists[k] with the monoms which have k 1s. So lists[k] = L_i^M(k) for each 0 <= k <= 2^t, where t is the number of different entries for the signature initialized by the constructor.
Note: The maximum number of different sets is 1024, see the documentation of this class.
